rename.from: Error handling root shared folder symbolic link when ~ used for path on Linux
rename.to: Error handling root synced folder symbolic link when ~ used for path on Linux

body: Can you actually post the logs. It's not clear if symlink is the syncthing configuration or what
By log do you mean the daemon output? [stlog.txt](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/files/129443/stlog.txt)
I don't see the error you are talking about in the log, is the symlink synced, or is syncthings home directory symlinked?
Or is the folder as a whole symlinked?

The folder structure is:
Linux:
/home/usernamee/SyncFolderName <- Symlink
/mnt/Shared/SyncFolderName <- Folder mount point
Path given to SyncThing (config shared between Windows and Linux):
~/SyncFolderName

I'm not sure if the above clarifies the setup, the issue is not syncing a symlink, it's SyncThing finding the root folder through a symlink when the path provided to SyncThing has a ~ in place of the full path the the symlink. If the full path to the symlink in the home directory is provided there is no error. The error only happens on Linux. If I create a new folder in home and specify the path as ~/newFolder to SyncThing it finds the folder without error.

If I create a folder now, symlink to it from the home directory, and then set it up in syncthing with a ~/symlinkToOtherFolder it works (note I have to edit this after setup in the advanced setting, ~ is automatically converted to /home/user/ in the add folder dialogue). If another computer shares a folder with me, the trying to set it up with the symlink produces the "not a folder" error which is only seen in the GUI, the only sign of it in the log is that the log repeatedly says an error is cleared for the affected folders.

If you have any leads for where this might occur I'd be interested in investigating it. I'd guess it is probably an outdated check is occurring somewhere.

I also noticed that if I set up a folder up to share on Linux initially I can get away with specifying the path with ~/SyncedFolder until I share it to another device, whereupon the issue reappears. I've only tested adding a Windows system so I'm not sure if this would happen if a Linux system were shared to instead.

This is probably a case of some code using a trailing slash and some not. When starting up we make sure to add one, as ~/foo/ will correctly be interpreted as the folder ~/foo is pointing to, but ~/foo itself is the symlink and will probably cause the "not a directory" error somewhere...

So since SyncThing's code never has "not a directory" except where hardcoded in a different format from what I saw, the error is probably originating from a system call. It looks like "not a directory" is probably being pulled from one of the golang.org/x/sys/unix/zerrors_\* files, in this case zerrors_linux_amd64.

Any recommended sources for how to navigate Go source code, something [like this ](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5Ymoav0nNWQ&index=1&list=WL) would be helpful.

If you run with `STTRACE=whatever` (literally whatever, it doesn't matter what the value is) you'll get a line number for where the error is printed. You should be able to backtrace that to where it comes from.

Ok, so I'm pretty sure I've narrowed down the issue, but haven't been able to test and verify yet.

In [lib/scanner/walk.go line 489](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/21e116aa45a3c09953a51ba2a4aead1be7360ed0/lib/scanner/walk.go#L489) isDir() I believe is returning false for symbolic links. I think the fix is to add a check for info.Mode() != FileMode.ModeSymlink. I'm not familiar enough to tell where else checkDir() is used and what impact this change would have, but if it is used for folders other than the root folder then I'd guess the fix would be to created a dedicated checkRootDir() which allows for symbolic links?

issue.title: lib/model: Refactor CheckFolderHealth into separate methods

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
While attempting to fix #2782 I thought the problem was the CheckFolderHealth method, so I cleaned it up. That turned out not to be the case, but I think this is better anyhow.

It also moves the "create folder and marker if the folder was empty in the index" code to StartFolder where I think it makes better sense.

This is covered by a number of existing tests.
